title: Dual Action- Out the Front Automatic Both Ways Extender

description.text:
Simple device that requires a bit of hardware and springs. Once you have them you will have an automatic extend/ retract mechanism. As the slider is moved forward it builds tension in the central spring while simultaneously overriding the lock out. Once the spring is at the height of the tension the lockout is overcome and the slider slams forward, sling shooting the extended object forward until it becomes locked out by the forward lock out. By then then the "Slider" is reset at the front of the the case, ready for the same action to retract the object. 
I've included a plate with all the files and each one as singles. Also, the Google SketchUp! file.

I had an idea for this, I looked online and sure enough Nintendo has one already but it is only for the NEW 3DS XL not the original so that did me no good.
I made it stand on it's back so that it saves space, I have very little on my desk.
I moved the plug away from the contacts so that if the plug is facing the back of your desk that the lights on the top of the 3DS will be facing you so that you can see the charge status. I used Adafruits USB Micro-B Breakout Board for the power as I only have one 3DS charger and no jacks for it but I have a lot of cell phone chargers.
I used some M2 screws I had leftover from a quadcopter to hold the board in. The original charger is 4.6v 900ma so a 5v 1a cell charger will work fine, I have been using the same setup with a 3DS USB cable I have had for years but since it is 0.4v higher I am going to say use at your own risk, but it has worked fine for me. For the spring contacts I used a spring that I had from a spring assortment from home depot, I just unrolled it until it was straight and bent it around, I soldered the power wires to a couple brass washers again from home depot, and used a couple M3 screws that I had around from building computers. The bottome screws are from a eyeglass repair kit. I was thinking about seeing if Amazon has some small stick on rubber feet for the bottom.

author: glynius

title: Thingidiff: Visualizing 3D Model Diffs with Thingiview.js

description.text: With URLs at http://eclecti.cc/computergraphics/thingidiff-visualizing-3d-model-diffs-with-thingiview-js Thingiverse is an enormous resource for mostly open source, ready to print 3D objects. It conveniently has both a built in understanding of derivative objects and a web based 3D object viewer. It has no mechanism for combining the two though, making comparing any two objects a matter of either visual guesswork or downloading and comparing the files against each other. Thingidiff is my fork of Thingiview.js allowing for web based visual comparisons between related 3D objects. Colors and opacities can be set for faces that are the same in both objects or unique to one or the other. The obvious use cases for this are showing a diff between a derived object and its original or showing differences in revisions of a work in progress. Both of these cases are in evidence on the example page. Note that between this being my first project in Three.js or Javascript at all and the currently mercurial state of WebGL support in web browsers, there are probably going to be nits, bugs, or even outright computer exploding failures in your experience. I'm interested in bug reports though, if you would be willing to drop them on the github project's Issues page. The code itself is nearby.
Download from: https://github.com/nrpatel/thingiview.js Example setup at: http://n0r.org/thingiview.js/examples/client_side_diff.html

Just like the fillet and chamfer standards this is intended to give you an idea of the exact performance of your printer because we all know what looks good as an STL model doesn't necessarily look good when printed.  
This angle standard is a good way to let you play with perimeters and layer heights as well as the angles to see what the layers (strata) would look like when printed so you can create better looking models.

title: Julia Vase #011 - Heatwave

description.text:
Heatwave
Part of the Julia Vase collection:
http://www.thingiverse.com/virtox/collections/julia-vase
Circa 12.5 cm high.
About 11 cm diameter.
Three versions:
Solid - Use vase/perimeter print settings in your software
Shell - Use surface print option in software
Walls - Predefined walls 1.5 to 2mm Do you like/print our designs? We accept donations:
http://blog.virtox.net/2013/10/25/virtox-accepts-donations/
Or you can buy optimized prints in our Shapeways shop:
https://www.shapeways.com/model/1409456/julia-vase-011-heatwave.html?materialId=6

I printed the "Wall" file in Fluorescence Green PLA on an Up Plus with 0.3 mm layer thickness, no support, normal speed.
The green is nearly impossible to photograph ;-) I am currently printing the "Solid" file on an Up plus at 0.15mm with the 'surface' setting at fast speed. About two hours total time.
This setting results in a single perimeter vase with a thin bottom.
(It automatically removes the top) Strangely though, the "Shell" file printed on Up plus with surface option does not print the bottom. So Up software is bit funky. This file is for the "Shell" option in Up or the Vase/Spiral vase function in other software.

It's a Maze nothing more

In the Early Days, before there was Team Fortress, and before there was Quake, and before even Doom or Wolfenstein were ideas, in the Early Days when baudrate was a term yet unheard and then forgotten when 56K became the norm, in those Early days did we play Capture the Flag outside, with our very bodies, and in those Early Days we skinned our knees and laughed and played and lost and played 'til the shiny fireflies bid us return home to suckle from the hose of gardens and collapse into mud-streaked sleep. Zerg rushes of anonymous children punctuate summertime in Barrio de Zheng. They overrun the defenses, screen door swinging, slamming, swinging again. One on the Ouya, two on the xBox, three on the Wii, most doing end runs around their parents' summertime video game restrictions and conveniently not informing me of the fact. But enough of pixels and vectors and voxels, little ones. I shall teach you the Old Ways, swaddled in furs sufficiently nerdy to invest you mentally in the game before you become physically addicted to the running and laughing with others of your ilk, for the creaking of my joints is the harbinger of wisdom, and I know how to manipulate younglings as I was once manipulated. Go, now, and play, before Summer wanes and study begins anew, for the Early Days that belong to you will not last ever long. [Learn the rules for Capture The Flag IRL.](http://zheng3.com/?p=5551 )

I'm assuming that all 1/2" PVC is cut from the same thicket off the coast of South Carolina, but you may need to scale the diameter of your rings by some constant factor.  
I noticed some variance in the internal diameter of my PVC, so I designed the finial and butt spike with some wiggle room. You'Âll be filling that space with adhesive anyway.  
The rings should be snug but I recommend adding a drop or two of glue to hold them in place once you have them in position. They're not completely necessary but they will keep your flag from sliding down the mast.  
The butt spike is fairly dull and is designed so that the flag can be snatched from the ground by a running 7-year-old. Don't plant the flag too deeply.  
Use whatever cloth you have handy for the flag. An old t-shirt works great and won't require any cutting if you tie the sleeves to the mast.

Tool to precisely position the 6 pins needed to replace the SimonK BOOTLOADER on DYS SN20A ESCs (like the ones sold by RCExplorer.se) with a BLHeli BOOTLOADER.
Once the bootloader is replaced, ESCs with BLHeli firmware can be configured using BLHeli Suite 14.3 or later directly through flight controllers running Cleanflight/Triflight.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Assembly To complete this build you need:
1x M3x18 buttonhead screw
1x Ø5.5x10mm spring
6x long angled header pins
6x AWG26 or similar wire (100mm)
6x 10mm Ø2mm heat shrink tube
1x Arduino Nano
CA Clean up the prints if necessary. Assemble the tool by inserting a Ø5.5mm spring and putting it together with a M3x18 buttonhead hex screw. Place 6 big angled header pins in the top of the flashing tool. Make sure they are flush and touch the pads of the ESC perfectly. Secure with CA. Now solder the wires to the header pins making sure that they do not touch or short. Add heat shrink tube to isolate the pins. Solder the pins to the Arduino Nano accordingly: RST : 10
5V : 5V
GND : GND
SCK : 13
MISO: 12
MOSI: 11

How to use it - USE AT OWN RISK! Using BLHeli Suite 14.3 or later, create an Arduino ISP programmer on an Arduino Nano. (Make interfaces tab - Make Arduino Interface Boards: Nano w/ATmega328 - ArduinoISP Programmer (X)) When created use these settings to connect to the board:
Select ATMEL / SILABS Interface: (X) ATMEL ISP Interface (AVRDude)
ISP Prog: ArduinoISP (Arduino as ISP Interface) at 19200 baud Connect the pins to Arduino Nano accordingly: RST : 10
MOSI: 11
MISO: 12
SCK : 13
GND : GND
5V : 5V To flash new bootloader, first go to Expert tools tab and press Erase Chip.
Then go to Atmel ESC Setup tab and press Read setup. BLHeli Suite will now offer til flash the ESC. Choose DYS SN20A MULTI and press OK. Now choose BLHeli Bootloader instead of SimonK and press YES. Let BLHeli Suite do its magic :-)

title: A MakerBot TOM with attitude: RGB leds controlled by the status of the print process

description.text:
This is an idea to implement a functional design into my bot using color fades to represent a status. I want to add some custom print codes so any help will be nice because I am pretty new into working with the MakerBot firmware, etc! -Begin color -> to red (heating up)
-Red to Green fade (working, some extra effects maybe?, 2 or 3 steps between the print code)
-Green -> Light blue/blue (cooling, like the ABP cool down)
-Celebration colors now! :P and finally yellow or purple... or even XMAS mode, halloween mode, etc Here is a demo of the current hardware (leds and controller). Next step is to decode the controler signals to link the arduino, then hack the firmware :)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3imxHHYvRk (english of course is not my native language! haha, so sorry if you don't understand me) My first attempt was adding a page up/down feature to the Gen4 interface and it works great in my machine ( http://github.com/makerbot/G3Firmware/pull/76/files ), also it will be nice if I can add folder and sorting support (a complete pcless -and snappy- operation)

• Place the leds
  • Wire the led controller to power and to the led stripe. I replaced the original plug and soldered the power cables to +12 and gnd in the PSU
  • Wire the controller to the arduino ( ** Work in Progress, maybe some small cables below will work)
  • Upload the future modified firmware ( ** Work in Progress)
  • Modify the skeinforge parameters to add the custom M-codes ( ** need start to research this)

description.text:
I wanted to make a stand for my shaving brush that used minimal material and could preferably be printed without support.  
It also needed to look good, hence all contours and rounded edges.  
I have a Muhle shaving brush, but this should be suitable for other ones too.  
The print turned out very nicely, but did end up needing support material to print the lip from which the brush hangs.  
The part was designed with PTC Creo (formerly Pro/Engineer), and I can send the source file upon request.
I printed this on a UP! 3D Plus Printer, using minimal support material (set to 10 degrees) and 25% fill. The print took about 5 hours to complete with a z-resolution of 0.3 mm.

title: Cobblestone road for tabletop war games

description.text:
I didn't want to spend the money to get GF9 roads for my table, so I designed this.  The pattern is repeated, and when printing more than one they can be placed end to end and will match up at the edges.  
It is 70 mm x 210 mm, and to my eye it looks just right for 28mm scale miniatures.   
Please don't mind the Cipher in the photo, he's just mugging for the camera (which is to say it's the only photo of the road I have right now), and he's only about 50% painted.

I printed this in ABS at .2mm 5% infill, then treated this in an acetone vapor bath to smooth out the layers. Next time, I'll likely print in .1 to get smoother results.
I really had it painted quite nicely until I got all dry-brushy on it, and that kinda mucked it up. The good news is that with something like this I can just re-prime and re-paint and it won't hurt it. Depending on your printer, you might get QUITE a rough finish if you don't vapor it, but that's only because the detail is all in the X,Y and printers aren't great at that. I'm CONSIDERING modeling in some supports and printing it on its side. That might look better.

Im putting these files on here to give people insperation or ideas about creating other cnc machines with cheap parts common to reprap printers. These are the files i used to create a small 2.5 foot by 2.5 foot cnc plasma cutting table. It uses 608zz bearings 8mm linear bearings 8mm smooth rod's and 5/16 threaded rod. The main frame is 3/4 inch square tubeing. Its belt driven (gt2 belt i believe) and the motors are nema17's. My machine runs over usb to a grbl shield and arduino uno. The width of the machine is limited to the length of smooth rod you can find I bought 8mm smooth rod from mcmaster carr in 3 foot length's
The length of table is only limited by the 3/4 square tube length. you could easily make it 10 feet long if you wanted.
The video is of the machine test without the torch hanging off the carrage but i will be adding more video's soon.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZriSs5EG28c
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6nbUBhJI9kU
My plasma cutter has nasty RF noise issues im fighting but the cutting table is working awesome so far. I could see a design of this working for a geto laser cutter with modifications to the carrage for holding mirrors.

comments.text: Hi, we have chosen this servos because its speed makes Kame able to jump. Also, they work at 7,4V, and this allows us to plug them to the LiPo battery without any converter. At this time, I haven't a schematic, but the circuit its simple. The board used is a NodeMCU. Signal wires of the servos are just connected to its PWM pins. title: LM8UU Bushing Block for Folgertech i3

description.text: This is a remix of FlyingMashedPotatoes LM8UU bushing which I really love. They work really well and I highly recommend them if you are looking for a good bushing to replace your noisy bearings. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:631285 I have added a block to support the bed platform. Specifically for the Folgertech i3 printer. The "BushingBlock" file is a drop in replacement for the LM8UU bearings. The "BushingBlockFlat" file lets you add two supports to the side of the bed that originally only had one, but you will have to drill 4 holes in the acrylic bed platform for the zipties. The bed on this printer has always been an unstable mess, and very hard to level. This is my attempt to lock it down and make it more stable, and it's a huge improvement. Still works with thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:923023 (Y axis end stop)

The original idea with these skirts was to create a design for an AP setup on the Versacopter that would allow longer booms for bigger motors and props to lift a gimbal. With version 2 of these skirts I wanted to maximize internal space. In an effort to make as much room as possible inside the Versacopter, I took my original Versacopter MAX skirts which are 28mm tall and made them 43mm tall. I have also squared off the arm clamps which add 17mm in internal length. I didn't want to do much with the sides but when dealing with a small space every millimeter counts so I reduce them from 5mm wide down to 4mm wide which gives an extra 2mm of width. With this setup it is possible to install a Vector flight controller inside the Versacopter with room to spare. Due to how tall these skirts are you will need 50mm M3 screws for assembly. Please visit http://RcPartsHangar.com where I offer most of my designs for purchase.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116042 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=116042

NOTE: 3DFreezeMe found a few faults with this design and did a really nice remix of it, make sure you check it out before making this one... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1714715 Also check his Nema17 version... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1716423 This remix incorporates a few personal preferences over the original design. Uses Hobb-Golbin 5mm/8mm Drive Gear
http://www.filastruder.com/collections/e3d-spare-parts-and-accessories/products/hobb-goblin-5mm-id-drive-gear Uses 623 bearings
Ebay or Amazon Uses a Hooked End Extension Spring for filament tension
Pick up at local hardware store Uses E3D Embedded Bowden Coupling
http://www.filastruder.com/collections/e3d-spare-parts-and-accessories/products/embeddedbowdencoupling Added 2020 V-Slot mount Note: Use Slicer to rotate parts as needed to print, mirror the Arm for side two.

comments.text:
I remixed it (again) but now for a NEMA17 sized stepper motor, before someone askes. And someone will...
;-)
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text: Haha, you know they will :-)
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text:
Hi Sonny, thank you for sharing this remake of the Saintflint extruder! I really like the concept of the easy changing of the filament, which is kinda pain in the @$# on the original.
;-)
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text:
I assembled the extruder with the 623 bearings now, but their diameter is not sufficient to make contact with a MK8 drive gear and 1.75mm filament.
The filament can be freely pulled through (back and forth) and neither the bearing or MK8 gear is spinning.
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: I'll check it as soon as I can. I also wonder if the MK8 gear could have something to do with it!?!? This was designed around the Hobb-Golbin 5mm/8mm Drive Gear so that could be causing a clearance issue (not sure how they compare in size!?!?), either way I should be able to confirm the issue as soon as I get a chance to look at the files and hardware...
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text:
The dimensions of both gears are simular, although the teeth of the MK8 seem a little more 'hollowed out' than the Hobb-Goblin.
I have printed the arms again, now slightly scaled up using Simplify3D: x=102%, y=110%, z=105% (when first laying flat on the side).
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: Thanks for the hard work you are putting into testing this extruder, I hope others appreciate it as well. I though friction would be enough as well as the fact it can and only moves when removing or loading filament (or possible on skipped steps as indicated). You could add a drop of glue when you install it to keep it in place, you could also drill and tap a 3mm hole on both sides of the upper part to secure the tube with small set screws (grub screws).
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text:
Thanks for the suggestions. Ever tried glueing teflon?
;-)
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: Yes I have, it works okay when inserting a tube into a hole like this, the key is to really rough up the outside surface of the tube, that way the adhesive (glue) has something to bite on. I'm not sure it actual adheres, it just sort of "locks" it in...
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text: That is a way to do it, good thinking.
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: Yeah, I was a Solidworks guy, but to be honest I think I have now made the permanent move to Onshape. It's not without it's share of shortcomings, but it's so damn close and I seem to find work arounds when I get hemmed up. My only real issue is the lag I get when my larger documents are open, it's tolerable though.
comments.author: 3DFreezeMe

comments.text:
It is getting there, a lot of nice updates have been added since the start. I like it very much, although sometimes a little sluggish like you said.
My previous experience was mainly with SketchUp Pro. Which is not really meant for 3D printing design work, as the .STL export does create broken files with lot of errors.
comments.author: sonnylowe

comments.text: Hi Sonny- have imported to Onshape in private only at present attributed to you by filename. If you want I will publish public to promote further collaboration. I have attached a readme & license file at end to maintain your creative commons copyright on any derivatives. Here is the view-only link so you can take a look-see: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/516e36e18a73e059673557d9
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Nice work, and wow, that was fast...I need more practice with OS ;-)
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Hi Sonny- like your design! A little cleaner than the original I think, and very easy to load/unload by simply pinching the levers- nice! I want to attempt a low torque 1/2 height Nema 17 (0.6A) version using MK7 drive gear by using your design as basis for direct drive instead of bowden. Is your source published to on Onshape?
comments.author: thetekguy

description.text: This is a big reprap. 730 x 515 x 800mm the main body is made of mdf boards. basically made from case-rap 4.0 parts. I had to changes some minor things but case-rap 4.0 is design I know well enough, guess why! I did use 2 motors for the y carriage and they are plugged in parallel on the board. the y carriage is made of plywood. with the auto tramming with a capacitive sensor, even if it not straight, it follows the curves. I'm actually impressed of this technology. You'll not have all informations and files to be able to build you're own, but now you know it's possible. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uzopqvw4ujc

comments.text: How do you go about leveling such a gigantic print bed?
comments.author: Toranado3D

comments.text: I used auto bed leveling with a capacitive sensor. And I'm impressed about it. I choose 6 as the number of readings so it makes 6x6 36 readings. What impresses me is that it follows the curves of the plywood.

comments.text: This is an unpractical design. when going large scale like this a moving xy like head is preferable. you will have very limited speed in your y axis. which makes the huge print that could take 12 hours take like 24. deltas are also great but can be a pain to calibrate. keep improving! :) good job anyways. it looks very professional!

description.text: I made these for Annelies' and my wedding in October.  They're made to be attached to little plastic bags with Texas pecans in them, but they can also be used for window ornaments.

A robot hand, printable ready to use. No assembly required! To make this happen, I designed a special joint: no overhangs exceeding 45°  
Modeled in Rhino.

The idea: Just print out the hand (hand.stl) on an Ultimaker, a MakerBot, a RepRap, or another sufficiently capable 3D printer. Note: There are gaps between parts as small as 0.5 mm! I suggest first printing a single joint (joint.stl). If the joint does not move, then scale the model up. If it is too loose, then scale the model down. Let me know if you need something, for example an STL mesh with different density. Bernhard Kubicek has successfully printed a scaled up joint. See the photo, as well as his blog post: Printing a part of a robotic hand…

comments.author: feklee

comments.text: I'm printing your design at 100% scale on my Gen-4 TOM with Mk7 extruder as I write this.  It's into it's 10th to 12th layer or so, and printing very well so far (no plastic warp, and very nice looking profiles so far).  However, I have my doubts that any of the joints will actually work.  The joints all look far too close together to ever work, and due to the scale of the object, I don't believe there is enough material strength to allow forcing and residual material to break away and allow the joints to work.  (We'll see when the print is finished.)
comments.author: clintkc

description.text: My wife asked me whether I could make a "diagonally decomposed cube" to get her maths students thinking about other kinds of pyramids than the classic one with the "summit" above the centre point of the square base.

Printer:

Velleman K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm

Infill:

Hexagonal

I designed it in SketchUp by taking a cube and then doing some trig to figure out the angles I'd need to rotate two large flat planes so I could slide them through the cube to "cut" it into the pyramid shape. I exported it as STL from SketchUp then ran it through Microsoft's 3D Model Repair Service (URL below), sliced it with Slic3r and sent it to my Velleman K8200 with Repetier-Host. http://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ The original design has the square base of the pyramid with 3cm sides but you can scale it as you see fit. You will need 3 to make a cube :-) Beware that the way up I printed it, I found the tip wasn't cooling fast enough so got a bit squished. I used a metal file to tidy up the "blob". The blue one I printed last and got additional cooling for that stage so that one came out better. I would consider printing these again but with the pyramid on its side such that the last to print is an edge not a dot in case that helps the heat dissipate more quickly.

comments.text: I've been looking for this for so long! Definatly printing one for my favorite math teacher! Thank you!

remixed_from.author: belrius
remixed_from.title: CCG deck box with geared pivoting lid

title: Magic: The Gathering Hinged Deck Box Resized

description.text:
Thanks to Belrius for the initial design ASSEMBLY IMAGES CAN BE SEEN HERE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20431 When I printed the original box from Belrius I found that the deckbox was not quite wide enough to fit 60 sleeved cards with a 15 card sideboard. I decided to download the SCAD file and edit parameters, but I had issues with a few of the parts, so I took the liberty of redesigning those parts and they are reuploaded here. Pins -- the ones from Belrius were wayyy too tight, so I designed new pins that slip in, but are a very snug fit. Deck Sides -- These new sides have slightly wider holes for the fitment of the inner lift rack. Still requires the use of extreme force (ie mallet) to assemble the internet framing. Small/Large Hinge -- I could not get the hinge layout to export as an stl from Belruis' design, so i completely redesigned them. The deck face with skull was taken from Chriscrewdson's remix of Belrius' design. If you print this resized box, please post a "Made It" so I know that I'm not the only one my files work for! Thanks,
Ross Edit: Apparently Gearbox 3 was causing MakerWare to crash, so I uploaded a working version. Edit 2: I've gone through all the files again and repaired anything people said they were having issues with. If you're still having issues continue to let me know.

title: Snowboard Stomp Pad - Star Wars Imperial Crest

description.text: Need a stomp pad for your snowboard?  I printed this in white ABS and stuck it onto a black board.  Included a two piece file and a one piece file where the inner and outer rings are connected.  Recommend printing with 90+% infill to avoid ever getting water trapped inside the infill.  I used 3M hi-strength spray adhesive to attach and it worked quite well.  If you wish to make any modifications, the original CAD file is in Onshape's public document cloud.

title: Ultipanel beta: Ultimaker autonomous printing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: Newer version with encoder schematics: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15081 This panels enable you to set parameters from the firmware (e.g. max-speeds, accelerations and such, and store the settings in eeprom).
You can choose file from the sd card, and print them.
Also, you can home, monitor temperature, and do other fancy stuff. It requires my fork of the Marlin/reprap firmware:
https://github.com/bkubicek/Marlin
In the configuration, you have to enable ULTIPANEL For true autonomous printing, you have to connect a 12V fan output to Vin pin on the Ultimaker PCB, so the arduino is powered by the 12V created from the 19V supply. Direct connection is not recommended, 12V is safer. The design is rather bad, and a new panel is in nearly finished right now.
The large PCB are makes in unreasonable to produce.
Its a proof of concept mainly. There are two single-sided PCBs, one carrying the LCD, the other the interactive parts.
The are videos of the whole thing in action: Initially the menu used all available keys
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B9uFdrKghi0 Now marlin features a new menu system, that Joris helped design. Its only uses the encoder to turn, and one click button, that in the production version will an encoder-push-button.
http://youtu.be/4pL8Y0NA92c

Parts needed:
3 3k3 resistor
3 1k8 resistor
1 470 resistor pre-transistor
8 10k-20k 0805 resistor pull-up
SD-Card adapter Hirose reverse type HRS163-3416A 130511RB
2n3904 Transistor
74hct165.
Piezo beeper continous noise, internal drive, 5V
20x4 LCD
2 air wires (red)
2* 2x5 connectors for the cables the ultimaker pcb. female+male header for the lcd
female+male header for the switches. Switch PCB:
4 mutltimec navimec key+cap RA3ATL6
2 multimec navimec red-key plus central ring cap: RA3FTL6M
1 rather large leftover rotary encoder. Prob. alps. I had bought 8 years ago, and have no more info, sorry.

title: Roman Arches: Design Challenge #4 Support Material

description.text:
Western Civilization class got me thinking..... "What if I could recreate the Roman architecture that I've loved to learn about?" With this figure, a Roman arched hallway is about an hour away! One huge hallway goes down the middle, along arches crossing this hallway that allows you to imagine the time. 
Note: Would not work very well in real life, my model doesn't have enough support on the sides of the columns, it would probably fall under it's own weight! Oh well, it looks pretty neat anyway.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%, Just like a plastic toy

Notes: Pretty straight forward print, just make sure to include the support material and raft.

comments.text: This is an awesome design! I I can picture some little figurines under it. :)
comments.author: MandyRae

comments.text: Yeah, I should make one a little higher so that it can fit some little makerbot robots underneath. I like the idea!
comments.author: MandyRae

title: Finn's Demon Blood sword from Adventure Time

description.text:
Available for purchase at http://etsy.me/17mgSRW
It wouldn't be an adventure without a sword made of Demon's Blood!
Note: sword is likely not adventure ready; if you strike just about anything with it, it is likely the sword will break before whatever you are slashing at. But it makes for an awesome costume piece!

Print out one of each, except for 'pin 2' which you will need 6 total.
Assembly is then pretty straight forward, snap pieces together with pins. The hilt is probably the trickiest print because of it's size, but just about all of them require the bed to be very well leveled.
The final sword might be kind of wobbly --- if you apply a liberal amount of super glue to each pinpeg as you assemble, the final product will be a lot more sturdy.

comments.text: I rescaled the pins at 0.95/1.
comments.author: freebeeromg

comments.text: I'm reading a lot of reviews of poor sturdiness. Might I suggest revising this thing so that a section of 5/16 all-thread is fed throughout all the parts, and somehow synched together.
comments.author: dowhilegeek

comments.text: how big should it be
comments.author: smokeycoma4

comments.text: The assembled sword is just under 2 feet. But you can add as many middle segments as you like, we've built it up to 4 feet before (though it gets a little top heavy)
comments.author: smokeycoma4

comments.text: Were supports used?
comments.author: smperez

comments.text: Don`t need them except on the hilt - print it flat with supports in the holes.
comments.author: smperez

comments.text: For the blades, I used 4-5 shells for it to be sturdy, but a low infill (5-10%). For the hilt, it was more like 3 shells & 15% infill. The handle doesn't really matter. Layer height need not be finer than .3mm really on any of these prints. The pins I printed extra stiff in order to hold the thing together better. For best results, I usually insert the pins along with some super glue to make the thing feel extra solid. You might need to do some dremmeling or sanding; the platform has to be super super level or there will be some unsightly gaps between blade pieces.
comments.author: 3DCentralVA

comments.text: So, I think my 11-yr old is going to be Finn for Halloween and this print is perfect for his costume (thanks!).  What settings did you use for these pix?  # of shells?  % fill?  layer height?  Also, the model file I downloaded looks like lower rez than these pix - do you have the original models that I can use for a slightly higher resolution *.stl (especially the curves of the hilt) or could you upload a higher rez version that doesn't have quite the level of faceting that this one does?
comments.author: NerdAlert3D

comments.text: Is the hilt the biggest piece?
comments.author: Hulksmash

comments.text: Yeah, the hilt has the largest footprint. But it should fit no problem on most printers, it fits (just barely) on my Up! plus, and comfortably on the Replicator.
comments.author: Hulksmash

Fits a standard 1-1/2"(40mm) x 3/4" (20mm) single edge razor blade
Use a paper clip to push the blade in and out.
I use one of these everyday for work, the flat pointy end to poke through tape and the razor end to open all sorts of envelopes. I've used openers like this before but you couldn't replace the blade. Next version the blade will sit at a steeper angle.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

0-15

Notes: Print standing up. The orientation when loaded should be correct. I've printed with 0 infill and 15 infill. At 20% infill the outside starts to get rough.

comments.text: I can't get my blade to stay in place. I don't even need to use the paper clip hole to push it out. Any suggestions?
comments.author: thetillmiester

comments.text:
The easiest way without modifying the model is to run it under hot water and pinch the opening to make it tighter. Then put the blade in. The blade is only held in by friction. I have used some blades that are not as thick as others and they slide in and out too easy.
What blades are you using?
comments.author: thetillmiester

comments.text:
Way Kool.. Simple but thought out design!
I love it.
comments.author: Pergo

comments.text: Thank you! There where a lot of alterations before I settled on this. When I have some more time I will work on the angle of the blade but I'm glad you like it!
comments.author: Pergo
